Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_bus_close:
```c
static void metal_linux_bus_close(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		if (ldrv->sdrv)
			sysfs_close_driver(ldrv->sdrv);
		ldrv->sdrv = NULL;
	}

	sysfs_close_bus(lbus->sbus);
	lbus->sbus = NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_bus_close:

static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}

explanation: I did not find any explicit compiler-specific language extensions (no use of __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, or other vendor-specific keywords) in the provided function body or struct definitions. The loop macro for_each_linux_driver as defined uses only standard C constructs (array-to-pointer decay, pointer increment, pointer used in boolean context) which are not compiler extensions — it is flagged here because macros can hide non-standard implementations elsewhere, so it should be inspected to confirm it is purely standard. The call to metal_container_of is flagged because its implementation was not provided; common implementations are standard (using offsetof), but many projects implement container_of using compiler extensions (e.g., typeof or statement expressions). Everything else in the shown code (static function, pointer assignments, NULL usage, structure definitions, function pointer members, sysfs_close_* calls) uses standard C and does not need further investigation for compiler language extensions.
